sentence: It is an honor and a pleasure to participate in the ECB Forum on Central Banking, and I thank you, President Draghi, and other members of the ECB Board, for inviting me to take part.1 Although the topic of the conference is inflation and unemployment, I will take another perspective by discussing some of the past, present, and future challenges that have and may in future confront the ECB and the euro area.

sentence:
Despite the fact that political and economic aspects of the structure of the European economy have inherently been closely intertwined throughout history--and saying this, one thinks of the Romans and later of Charlemagne--I will focus on the economic aspects of the European project, and primarily on its monetary and financial aspects.6 

       Intra-European monetary and exchange rate problems have for centuries bedeviled European countries and intra-European trade, and led to the desire for greater exchange rate stability--perhaps through some form of treaty or agreement, or even through a monetary union.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the historical context and challenges of the European economy. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on US monetary policy.

sentence: Of course, the desire for greater exchange rate stability is true also of almost the entire world, and is reflected in the original Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the desire for exchange rate stability globally and refers to the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund. It does not provide any indication of a hawkish, dovish, or neutral stance on US monetary policy.

sentence: The first modern international attempt to regularize monetary relations among independent European states was that of the Latin Monetary Union (LMU), which came into force in 1866.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the historical establishment of the Latin Monetary Union in Europe. It does not provide any implications or insights on the current stance of US monetary policy, making it unrelated and irrelevant.

sentence: The Papal States joined later in the same year, and Greece and Rumania joined in 1867.7 The members agreed to fix exchange rates among them by setting the amounts of silver and gold (weights and fineness) in the national coinage, with a specified exchange rate (15.5) between silver and gold.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it discusses the historical joining of countries and the fixing of exchange rates based on silver and gold. It does not provide any information or implications on the current stance of US monetary policy, making it irrelevant.

sentence:
"8 

       The LMU fixed exchange rates within a bimetallic international system.
reason: This sentence is irrelevant to US monetary policy as it refers to the historical practice of fixed exchange rates within a bimetallic international system, which is no longer relevant in the current monetary framework.

sentence: "Then came a series of blows to silver" (p. 68), the most important occurring after the establishment of the Reichsbank, when Germany in 1873 shifted from bimetallism to the gold standard, and the Reichsbank started selling its silver.

sentence: In practice this moved the LMU to a gold standard, a change that was formally recognized in 1878--the year of the International Monetary Conference called by the United States to maintain bimetallism, an effort which failed.

sentence: Of particular difficulty to members of the EEC, under some circumstances the exchange rate bands specified in the Smithsonian agreement permitted movements of up to 9 percent between any pair of currencies.

sentence: In response to these pressures, members of the EEC agreed in 1972 to the so-called "snake"--or "the snake in the tunnel"--that attempted to limit exchange rate fluctuations of each currency relative to the dollar.10 However, this system was soon tested, notably by the oil crises of the 1970s, as both the effects of the oil price increases themselves and the policies adopted in response differed across countries.
